Writer

I’ve been writing semi-regularly on the web since 2004, when I first started my personal blog: The Watchmaker Project.

(Curious about the name? I wrote about the reasons for my choice in 2005.)

Writing online has changed a lot since then. The insular ‘blogosphere’ of the mid-2000s is long gone, and the advent of Tumblr and Twitter has pretty much killed long-form blogging. Like many others, I tend to write less about web design now and more about myself, although it’s still sometimes hard to let go of the feeling you are writing for an audience. In recent months I’ve also made a conscious effort to write more; Jeffrey Zeldman once said: “You don’t know what you think if you don’t write” — I think that’s very true, but equally there is a limit to how much personal insight one can derive from one’s Twitter timeline.

So I started two new blogs.

This Reviewer’s Life

Writing about working on the web is hard. It takes research, prototyping, testing, coding — plus endless follow-up as new readers try to use the techniques you have recommended.

So, to encourage myself to write regularly, I created This Reviewer’s Life, a separate blog dedicated to reviewing stuff. It’s mostly books and films, with the occasional album thrown in for variety. It’s fun to write and research, and can reveal opinions I didn’t even realise I had until I wrote them down.

Ten Minutes of Prose

My second new blog is a daily writing exercise. All of the posts on Ten Minutes of Prose are exactly that — five minutes of writing, followed by five minutes of editing. It’s close to the idea of flash fiction, but I make no claim to be creating self-contained stories — there are no beginnings and endings here, just free-flowing exercises in imagination and copy-editing. My hope is that eventually I can look back at these short pieces and see my writing improve over time, both in conception and execution.
